childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1963-1975

The smell of Coppertone suntan lotion. The satisfying click of a View-Master reel. The crinkle of wax paper around your bologna sandwich. Your childhood had a texture that kids today will never know—everything was tactile, analog, present in ways that screens can never replicate.

At one, you were oblivious to the Beatles landing at JFK Airport, but by five you knew every word to 'I Want to Hold Your Hand' and 'She Loves You.' Your older siblings had Beatles wigs. Your mother had opinions about their hair. The British Invasion soundtrack played through your entire childhood—Herman's Hermits, The Animals, The Rolling Stones blasting from transistor radios that ran on nine-volt batteries.

Your toys had heft. Lincoln Logs that smelled like actual wood. Erector Sets with metal pieces sharp enough to draw blood. The Easy-Bake Oven that debuted the year you were born, using a lightbulb to make tiny cakes that tasted like cardboard but felt like magic. Creepy Crawlers that produced rubbery bugs from Plastigoop. G.I. Joe arrived when you were one—the original 12-inch version with the scar, not the tiny ones that came later.

Saturday mornings meant one thing: cartoons. You planted yourself in front of the TV for The Jetsons, The Flintstones, and Jonny Quest. By the time you were seven, Scooby-Doo premiered and you never looked at foggy nights the same way. The TV Guide arrived weekly, and you circled shows with a pen like you were planning a military campaign.

You ate TV dinners on metal trays—Swanson's fried chicken with the little compartments for mashed potatoes and corn. Tang, the drink of astronauts, turned your tongue orange. Pop-Tarts had just been invented. Your mom served casseroles with Campbell's Cream of Mushroom soup as the base for everything. Jell-O molds appeared at every family gathering, sometimes with fruit suspended inside like insects in amber.

At six, you watched Neil Armstrong step onto the moon. Your dad lifted you up to see the grainy black-and-white images on your Zenith console television. The adults cried. You didn't fully understand why until much later—that this was supposed to be the beginning of something magnificent, not a peak we'd never reach again.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Baby Boomers

Baby Boomer. The label stuck, even though you arrived at the tail end of the boom—sometimes called 'Generation Jones,' the ones who came too late for Woodstock but too early for disco's embarrassments. You're part of the 76 million Americans born between 1946 and 1964, the demographic earthquake that reshaped everything from school construction to Social Security projections.

JFK was assassinated the year you were born. You don't remember it, but it marked your generation like an invisible scar. Your parents remember exactly where they were—the kitchen, the office, the car. For them, it was the death of a certain kind of American optimism. For you, it was a historical fact you absorbed through osmosis, the first line of your origin story.

As a 1963 baby, you occupy an odd position. At five, you were too young to understand why cities were burning in 1968 or why your parents watched the news with clenched jaws every night. At eleven, you were old enough to understand Watergate but young enough that Nixon's resignation felt more confusing than cathartic. You caught the shrapnel of the sixties without experiencing the actual explosion.

Your generation controls more wealth than any in American history. You bought houses when they cost three times the median income, not ten. You had pensions, actual pensions, that companies funded and honored. You watched those same systems get dismantled the moment you were done using them, and younger generations have strong opinions about that timing.

The criticism stings because some of it is fair. Not you personally, necessarily, but your cohort voted for policies that prioritized present consumption over future investment. The infrastructure is crumbling. The climate is changing. The social safety net has holes. You inherited a functional system and... well, the receipts are extensive. The question now isn't guilt—it's what you do with however many years you have left.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year you were born, The Fugitive premiered on ABC—Dr. Richard Kimble chasing the one-armed man across America. Petticoat Junction and My Favorite Martian debuted. Hitchcock released The Birds, teaching a generation to eye seagulls with suspicion. The Beach Boys released 'Surfin' USA' and made landlocked kids dream of California waves.

Your childhood ears absorbed Motown's golden age. At three, you heard 'My Girl' by The Temptations for the first time. At four, 'Stop! In the Name of Love' by The Supremes was inescapable. By five, you could identify Marvin Gaye's voice before the first word ended. Stevie Wonder, The Four Tops, Martha and the Vandellas—the Motown assembly line produced the soundtrack of your early years with factory precision.

Television in your childhood ran on three channels and ended at midnight with the National Anthem. You watched The Andy Griffith Show and dreamed of a Mayberry that probably never existed. Bewitched made you wish your nose could twitch magic into existence. I Dream of Jeannie, Gilligan's Island, The Munsters, The Addams Family—each one became a cultural landmark you'd reference for the rest of your life.

At nine, Sesame Street premiered, too late for you but perfect for your younger siblings. At ten, you watched the final episode of The Monkees, a show you'd loved without irony despite adults insisting they weren't 'real' musicians. At twelve, M*A*S*H began its eleven-year run, processing Vietnam through the safe distance of Korea. Happy Days started when you were eleven, selling nostalgia for the fifties to kids who'd never experienced them.

Movies grew up with you. At nine, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid. At eleven, The Godfather—you probably didn't see it in theaters, but you absorbed its quotes through cultural osmosis. At twelve, American Graffiti made you nostalgic for a decade you barely remembered. At fourteen, Jaws kept you out of the ocean. At fourteen, Star Wars rewired your brain for spectacle.

You were seventeen when MTV launched on August 1, 1981. 'Video Killed the Radio Star' was literally the first thing you saw. Michael Jackson's 'Thriller' video was a movie unto itself. Madonna rolled around on stage at the VMAs in a wedding dress. Prince made purple a lifestyle choice. The eighties were excessive, synthesizer-heavy, and weirdly optimistic after the grind of the seventies.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The push-button telephone was introduced the year you were born, but your family probably kept the rotary dial until it physically fell apart. You can still feel the resistance of that dial, the satisfying whir as it spun back to zero, the way long-distance calls felt like events that required planning and permission because they cost actual money.

At three, you watched your first color television broadcast—probably at a neighbor's house, since color TVs cost more than some cars. At five, your family might have gotten their own. The switch from black-and-white to color felt like Dorothy landing in Oz. Bonanza in color. The Wonderful World of Disney in color. Everything felt more real and less real simultaneously.

Your childhood technology was magnificently analog. Slide rules for math. Typewriters with ribbons that smeared. Cameras that required dropping film at the drugstore and waiting a week for disappointing prints. Record players with needles that wore down. Eight-track tapes that changed songs mid-word. The smell of mimeograph paper fresh from the school office, that strange purple ink you'd huff before tests.

At fifteen, the pocket calculator arrived—$150 for something that could add, subtract, multiply, and divide. Your parents couldn't believe you needed it. At sixteen, Pong appeared in arcades, and suddenly screens could be interactive. At eighteen, the Apple II launched. At twenty, the IBM PC arrived. You watched the computer revolution happen in your twenties, adapting mid-career to technology your parents never touched.

The internet arrived when you were thirty-two—or rather, the World Wide Web became accessible. Email replaced memos. Websites replaced catalogs. You were forty-one when Facebook launched, forty-four when the iPhone appeared. Unlike your kids, you remember life before connectivity. You know how to read a paper map. You can calculate a tip without a phone. You remember phone numbers because you had to.

Your relationship with technology is practical, earned through adaptation rather than absorption. You use what works and ignore what doesn't. You have a smartphone but remember when being unreachable was normal, even desirable. That memory is becoming valuable—you know something younger generations never learned: how to be bored, how to wait, how to exist without constant stimulation.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

Where were you when Kennedy was shot? You were in a crib, too young to remember. But you grew up in the aftermath—the Warren Commission, the conspiracy theories, the collective wound that never fully healed. Your parents remembered exactly where they were. That specificity of grief became a template: where were you when MLK was shot, when RFK was shot, when the Challenger exploded, when the towers fell.

At five, Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert Kennedy were assassinated two months apart. Cities burned. The National Guard rolled through American streets. Vietnam was in the living room every night, body counts delivered between commercials for cigarettes and laundry detergent. At seven, Kent State—National Guard troops shooting college students. Your childhood was punctuated by gunfire and flags at half-staff.

At six, you watched Apollo 11 land on the moon. July 20, 1969. You were old enough to understand this was important, young enough to believe it was just the beginning. Mars by 1980, they said. Colonies in space. Instead, the program wound down, and America turned its attention earthward, toward problems that felt less solvable than rocket science.

At eleven, Watergate began unraveling. You watched hearings instead of cartoons, absorbed phrases like 'executive privilege' and 'Saturday Night Massacre.' At eleven, Nixon resigned—the second presidential exit of your conscious life, after JFK's assassination. At twelve, Saigon fell. Helicopters evacuating the embassy. Vietnam ending not with victory but with scrambling retreat.

At sixteen, the Iran hostage crisis began. Yellow ribbons everywhere. Nightline tracking each day of captivity. At eighteen, Reagan was shot, surviving what had killed Kennedy. At nineteen, AIDS began killing, though nobody called it that yet—just a 'gay cancer' that the government ignored until the bodies piled too high to overlook.

At twenty-six, the Berlin Wall fell. You watched strangers with sledgehammers attacking concrete, champagne flowing, tears streaming. The Cold War you'd grown up with—duck-and-cover drills, fallout shelter signs, mutually assured destruction—simply ended. At thirty-eight, you watched the towers fall, probably on live television. Another 'where were you' moment, another scar on the collective memory. You'd lived through more history by forty than most generations see in a lifetime.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Let's talk about what you walked into, because the context matters.

You graduated college around 1985, give or take. Interest rates had been 20% a few years earlier. Unemployment had peaked at 10.8% in 1982. Reagan was rebuilding confidence through sheer force of personality and deficit spending. By the time you entered the workforce, the recovery was underway. You got lucky with timing, though it didn't feel lucky at the time—it just felt normal.

Your generation is the last to remember when employment was a relationship, not a transaction. You joined companies expecting to stay. They expected you to stay. There were training programs, mentorship tracks, pension plans that vested over decades. The implicit contract was loyalty for security. That contract was shredded by the nineties—downsizing, restructuring, shareholder value replacing stakeholder responsibility—but you caught the tail end of the old world.

Women of your generation faced choices that barely existed for their mothers and barely make sense to their daughters. Work or family was presented as binary, either/or. The women who pushed through—enduring harassment that was called 'flirting,' discrimination that was called 'how things are'—changed what was possible. Some of you were those women. Some of you watched them. All of you lived through the transition.

Technology disrupted your career mid-stream. You learned to type on typewriters, then adapted to word processors, then to email, then to whatever platform your company decided was essential that year. Each transition sorted workers into adapters and resisters. The adapters got promoted. The resisters got packages. You probably know people in both camps.

You're the generation that accumulated—houses that appreciated, 401(k)s that compounded, equity that grew. Not because you were smarter or harder-working than the generations that followed, but because you bought assets before they became unaffordable and held them while they tripled in value. Timing isn't everything, but it's a lot. The question now is what you do with what you've accumulated, and who benefits after you're gone.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember waiting by the phone? Literally waiting, because the phone was attached to the wall and you couldn't take it with you. If you missed a call, you missed a call. If someone wanted to reach you and you weren't home, they'd try again later. The anxiety of connectivity didn't exist because connectivity didn't exist. Unreachability was the default state, and somehow civilization persisted.

You probably met your partner through physical proximity—work, school, church, a friend's party, a bar. There were no algorithms, no profiles, no swiping. You made eye contact across a room, or you were introduced by someone who thought you'd get along. The serendipity of meeting someone attractive at the right moment in the right place was the whole system. It worked often enough to propagate the species.

Your generation married younger than any since. The average first marriage age in the mid-eighties was 23 for women and 25 for men. You probably hit those benchmarks within a few years. Divorce rates peaked around the same time—your parents' generation was splitting up while you were trying to figure out how to make marriage work. You learned what not to do by watching them fail.

Long-distance relationships before cell phones meant scheduled calls, expensive minutes, and letters that took days to arrive. Missing someone meant actually missing them—not seeing their Instagram, not watching their TikTok, not tracking their location. The absence was complete, which made presence more precious. Your kids will never understand what it felt like to see someone after months apart, to hold a letter they'd touched, to hear a voice you couldn't summon at will.

You raised kids during the digital transition. You made decisions about technology that your parents never faced and your kids take for granted. How much TV is too much? When do they get a computer? What about video games? Then cell phones appeared, then smartphones, then social media. You made rules based on intuition because there was no precedent. Some rules worked. Some didn't. Your kids will tell you which were which.

You're probably grandparents now, or watching it approach. Your relationships with adult children span technologies—texts, FaceTime, photo streams, shared calendars. You see more of their lives than your parents ever saw of yours. Whether that visibility creates closeness or just the illusion of it is a question worth sitting with.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Your financial formative years were the 1970s—stagflation, gas lines, inflation eating savings, interest rates climbing to levels that sound fictional now. You learned that money could lose value just sitting there, that the economy could go sideways for a decade, that prosperity wasn't inevitable. This shaped how you thought about saving, spending, and security.

Then you got lucky. The early-eighties recession ended. Interest rates fell from 20% to single digits. The stock market began a bull run that lasted, with interruptions, for most of your working life. You bought houses when they cost three times the median income. You watched those houses triple, quadruple, quintuple in value while you lived in them. Your 401(k)s compounded in markets that mostly went up.

The numbers tell a story that younger generations find enraging. Boomers control over 50% of American household wealth—nearly $80 trillion. Your median net worth is around $970,000. Millennials at the same age had about $65,000. Gen X, squeezed between you, has about $180,000. The gap isn't because you worked harder. It's because you bought assets before they became unaffordable.

You bought a house in 1990 for $100,000. It's worth $500,000 now. You didn't do anything to earn that $400,000—you just lived there while markets appreciated. Your kids can't buy the equivalent house for less than half a million, on wages that haven't kept pace with housing costs. When you tell them to 'save more,' they hear someone who bought a car for $5,000 telling them to 'just budget' for a $50,000 car.

Your retirement, if you're there or approaching it, is better funded than any generation before or since. Social Security will likely survive your lifetime. Your pensions, if you had them, were funded. Your savings benefited from decades of compound growth. The anxiety you feel about money—and many of you do feel it, despite the numbers—is often disconnected from the math. Financial trauma from the seventies persists even when your portfolio doesn't justify it.

The question now isn't whether you have enough. Statistically, you do. The question is what happens to what you have—who inherits it, how it transfers, whether it helps your kids or just passes to their kids while they struggle through their peak earning years. Estate planning is the last major financial decision. How you make it says something about what you value.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest blind spot is survivorship bias, and it's understandable. You worked hard, made good choices, and things worked out. The natural conclusion is that hard work and good choices lead to things working out. But you also started the race closer to the finish line. Houses were cheaper. Education was affordable. Jobs came with benefits. The game was easier when you played it, and recognizing that doesn't diminish what you accomplished.

You may not see how much the rules changed. Your advice—'buy a house,' 'stay at one company,' 'save 10% and you'll be fine'—was true when you followed it. It's not wrong now; it's incomplete. The house costs six times the median income instead of three. Companies don't reward loyalty; they exploit it. Ten percent of a paycheck that doesn't cover rent doesn't compound into anything. The strategies that worked for you don't work anymore, and repeating them harder isn't wisdom.

Your generation sometimes treats systemic problems as personal failures. If millennials can't afford houses, they must be spending too much on avocado toast. If Gen Z seems anxious, they must be coddled. The alternative explanation—that housing costs tripled while wages stagnated, that climate change and mass shootings create rational anxiety—requires acknowledging that the world your generation built has structural problems. That's uncomfortable.

The defensiveness is understandable but counterproductive. 'OK Boomer' stings because it dismisses your experience, your contributions, your life. But some generational criticism is valid. Boomers voted for tax cuts without spending cuts, creating deficits their grandchildren will pay. Boomers resisted environmental regulation, creating problems their descendants will inherit. Boomers controlled Congress, state legislatures, and corporate boards during the decades when inequality exploded. The individual isn't guilty, but the cohort has a record.

Technology creates a gap that's easy to misread. Your grandchildren live in their phones not because they're addicted or antisocial, but because that's where their social world exists. Dismissing it as 'screen time' misses that for them, screens are as fundamental as phones were for you, as letters were for your grandparents. The medium changed. The human need for connection didn't.

The hardest thing to see is that your success, while earned, was also enabled. You earned your career, but you entered a job market that rewarded careers. You earned your house, but you bought in a housing market that was accessible. You earned your retirement, but you benefited from systems designed to support retirement. Luck isn't a dirty word. Acknowledging it doesn't diminish you. It just explains why your path isn't available at any price for those who follow.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1983-1993): You entered adulthood during the Reagan recovery. Interest rates were falling from their insane peaks. The job market was absorbing your generation because the economy was still growing. You probably found work that led somewhere—not necessarily your passion, but a paycheck, a path, a start. You might have married, bought a starter home for $60,000, started thinking about kids. The Cold War was winding down without anyone quite realizing it. The Berlin Wall fell when you were twenty-six. The Soviet Union collapsed when you were twenty-eight. The world was supposed to be different now.

Your 30s (1993-2003): The Clinton years brought balanced budgets and tech booms. Your career hit its stride. You had kids and suddenly cared about school districts, college savings, the kind of neighborhood you lived in. The internet arrived—dial-up modems screaming, AOL CDs everywhere, email replacing memos. Y2K was supposed to end civilization. It didn't. You entered the new millennium established, responsible, adult in ways that felt permanent and sometimes suffocating.

Your 40s (2003-2013): 9/11 happened when you were thirty-eight. The towers fell; the wars began. Afghanistan, Iraq, the War on Terror—your forties were shaped by conflicts your kids might be called to fight. The 2008 crash hit your 401(k), maybe your home value, certainly your sense of security. You recovered, mostly, because you had time. Your kids became teenagers, then adults, entering a job market that looked nothing like the one you'd entered. You worried about them in ways your parents probably hadn't worried about you.

Your 50s (2013-2023): Peak earning years, theoretically. Also peak responsibility—aging parents who needed care, adult children who needed help, grandchildren who needed attention. The sandwich generation, squeezed from both directions. Social media made it easier to stay connected and harder to escape. Political polarization made family dinners minefields. The pandemic hit when you were fifty-six or fifty-seven, either accelerating your exit from the workforce or reminding you how much you valued purpose. Either way, mortality got closer. You thought about it more.

Your 60s (2023-2033): You're here now. Retirement is happening, about to happen, or being renegotiated. Your health matters more than it used to. Your parents are gone or going. Your kids are fully adult, making choices you can advise but not control. Your grandchildren are growing up in a world that looks nothing like the one you grew up in—devices everywhere, anxieties you can barely name, a climate changing in real time. Your job now is figuring out what this phase means. Not what society expects, but what you actually want from however many years remain.

Your 70s and beyond (2033+): Late life. The concerns shift toward legacy, meaning, health, connection. You'll have lived through more history than most humans who ever existed—from JFK's assassination through the digital revolution, through pandemics and wars and social transformations your parents couldn't have imagined. You're a primary source now, a witness to a world that will be as foreign to your great-grandchildren as your grandparents' world was to you. What stories will you tell? What will you pass on? That's the work of this phase, and nobody can do it for you.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

4.1 million people were born in the US the same year as you—one of the largest single-year cohorts in American history, right at the tail end of the baby boom. You're part of the 76 million Americans classified as Baby Boomers, though that number shrinks each year as mortality claims its share. You've already outlived your life expectancy at birth, which was about 70 years.

Compared to the Silent Generation (born 1928-1945): They survived the Depression and fought World War II. You inherited their prosperity and questioned their conformity. They trusted institutions because institutions had saved them. You watched those same institutions fail—Vietnam, Watergate, corporate downsizing—and learned to trust differently. They're mostly gone now. The stories they could tell went with them.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): They're the forgotten middle child, sandwiched between your demographic dominance and Millennial cultural relevance. They entered the workforce just as the rules changed—pensions disappearing, loyalty unrewarded, job-hopping becoming survival strategy rather than character flaw. They're scrappier than you, more cynical, less attached to institutions you still believe in. They have some basis for resentment: they got the transitional economy while you got the old deals.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): The wealth gap is stark enough to cause family tension. You bought houses when they cost three years' salary. They rent apartments that cost half their income. You graduated into growth. They graduated into the Great Recession. You had pensions. They have student debt. The criticism of Boomers often comes loudest from this generation, and it's not baseless—they're living the consequences of decisions made before they could vote.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You're from different planets. They've never known a world without the internet, without smartphones, without the ambient hum of connectivity. They've never experienced true boredom—the productive kind that forces creativity because there's literally nothing else to do. Their anxieties are shaped by climate change, mass shootings, and economic precarity as permanent condition. They look at your generation and see people who had everything and left them with mounting problems. That's not entirely fair. It's not entirely wrong either.

Your life expectancy at birth was 70 years. You've beaten it. Medical advances, reduced smoking, better heart disease treatment mean you're likely to see your eighties, maybe longer. The question isn't just longevity—it's how you use the time. You've accumulated wealth, experience, perspective. What you do with those resources in the years remaining will shape how your generation is remembered. The story isn't over yet.

year_events: Martin Luther King Jr. delivered 'I Have a Dream'
The first push-button telephone was introduced
